On balance its actual performance should please some, displease some and mostly be found a welcome addition for those whose digital world is centered in the Amazon eco-system.  It all rather depends on what you are looking for--- even within the Amazon system.  As an owner of the iPad's every generation, a couple of iterations of various android tablets, iPods/iPhones and the odd e-reader, including the original kindle, I believe I have a better grasp than many on the real world factors which judge success and failure in such devices generally.Without trying to reinvent the wheel in this review or go too far afield in measurements and techno-speak, I feel a select group of factors are to the point particularly with this specific item and I will confine comments to those, so that a concise and understandable comparison with not only choices of other devices, but most importantly the unique and singular needs this one fulfills best.Specific factors: size, screen quality, form factor, durability, flexibility, value (cost/what you get) and continued satisfaction in longterm.This version of the Kindle has a number of capabilities: as a limited personal computing device for web-surfing, document handling and light office duty, as an ebook reader, streaming media player, etc., but not to get into the weeds of such a shopping list I will jump to the end and simply state that what it is or should be seen as is as a media player which occasionally is used for some of these other  tasks.  A laptop, even a lightweight and inexpensive ultra-book is going to do office jobs and web-surfing better, a couple of tablets, most notably the Nexus and the iPad are more flexible and higher powered for running apps, with greater libraries of apps to draw on even.  A smartphone is lighter and more portable.  However--beginning with a screen that is absolutely comparable with the deservedly touted retina display, a nimble combination of hardware components that make for stellar responsiveness-- especially for those persons within the Amazon Prime family, this tablet leaves all others in the dust for the breadth of high quality media (movies predominantly) delivered.As a streaming media device the amount of storage is of relatively minor impact as what is left of the baseline 16 gigs should absolutely be more than enough for a few apps, pictures, a moderately robust collection of audio books, books and music (think of this device as the equivalent of your everyday carry bag or commuter backpack for your media).  Since you are streaming your movie content from Amazon and have an infinite storage space for your Amazon content: books, audio books and music; you really shouldn't be storing much on it.If you are more about a purse or a briefcase or if what you are predominantly doing is reading ebooks then you need to look to the 7" little brother with its lower price, as the greater real estate of the 8.9 inch doesn't do for you or doesn't appreciably add, respectively.  Similarly, if your primary thrust is for your children, since it is easier in smaller hands and comes with all of the same services, the smaller/less expensive version is your sweet spot.It feels solid and sturdy, much more so than a number of similarly sized android tablets.  It has a nicely finished surface for gripping and has an edge to edge glass screen which is scratch resistant and tolerably low in reflective glare.  Though some reports have contested the claim of its speedy wifi connectivity, for streaming video it is second to none and flawless with no discernible stuttering, freezing or hiccuping for buffering.  The pricey, optional Amazon tablet cover/case preserves all the physical aspects of the tablet including its svelte lines, further extending its durability without turning it into a giant plastic brick.Finally, while including most every nicety you find on other tablets bluetooth, hdmi out, support for Exchange based corporate email, Skype and social media integration--- it adds a few of its own, Amazon specific extras like Read to me, Whispersync, integration into the Amazon shopping experience including product suggestions etc, the new X-ray function for most consumable content, a huge lending library of free books and a gigantic and heavily discounted textbook rental library-- making overall value untouchable (again for those in the Amazon system) by any of its tablet competitors.The single, largest deficit is the battery life.  While an improvement on the earlier version of the Fire, the 10 hour claim is pure marketing fantasy.  One of the real pluses, its thinness, doesn't leave enough room for a sufficiently sized battery. The real world battery usage will run between 6-71/2 hours depending on screen brightness being set anywhere from 50-100%.  While minimally acceptable, in the age of similar devices running in excess of 10 hours, this is far from ideal. On the flip side of that, with the speedy charger (which should be free, but isn't) the recharge time from near 0 to fully charged is considerably under the 5 hours they promise---taking roughly 3 1/2 hours or around 2 1/2 hours for 80%.The single biggest asset of the device is Amazon, itself.  Its track record, its overall services, but most of all its customer service--which in my considered opinion is not only light years ahead of its nearest rival, Apple, but in a consumer world of deception, built in obsolescence and recorded telephone loops...the closest thing to absolute perfection any of us will ever see from a business.  For this alone you may bank on the long term reliability and value of your purchase.Final thoughts:  I underscore that this is a media streaming device, if your primary thrust is something else, look elsewhere (though as an affordable electronic babysitter or a way of cutting textbook costs it may likewise prove the singular touchstone for those strongly of those needs).  The 4G LTE option is potentially a killer for Amazon, but not as it exists now.  Until Amazon can work out a deal with a cellular provider based upon the muscle of their client base so that an unlimited or at least a very large allotment per month (5-10 gigs) for a reasonable, flat yearly charge, it is all but useless.  For a media streaming device, what does the present allotment buy you in terms of streaming--1/2 of one movie?  Why would you pay double for the LTE version, essentially so you could do email and download that book which you JUST can't put off another 15 minutes until you reach home, office, Starbucks or the train? I don't think so!!If there were a percentage rating possible I would have given something in the mid to upper 80s, even with the very disappointing battery life, but with stars it has to be 4 until that one problem is substantially solved.  On balance, I love this device.

Reviews.Title: WOW!!!
Reviews.Author: V. Woyak
Reviews.Content: I am a first time ereader/tablet owner.  All I can say is, WOW! Oh, and now what do I do with my almost new laptop that is now going to collect a LOT of dust!!!  The Kindle's screen is so sharp and clear it's just amazing!!!  2 complaints however.  first, this is going to cost me some money because I want EVERYTHING it can do and all the books!!!!  Many of the coolest apps are free!!!  I love the "toys" on it as well, like the autoharp and piano. My only serious complaint is the inability to upgrade the flash player so I can play my favorite FB game on my Kindle.  I know this is not Kindle's fault, but am wondering what this will mean down the road since Flash player is no longer supporting the android format. Not seriously concerned however because I am sure someone will quickly come up with a fix, they always do :)Overall, any one considering the Kindle Fire Hd 8.9, WHAT ARE YOU WAITING FOR???

Reviews.Title: ATT service does not activate
Reviews.Author: caroline a strachan
Reviews.Content: I had to go to 3 different wifi locations to activate the Kindle but the ATT service never activated. I called Amazon twice and they said call ATT. So I called ATT and they said call Amazon. I have been bounced back and forth but no one can help me. I spent $500. for something that does not work.

Reviews.Title: Not a smart purchase
Reviews.Author: ChadK
Reviews.Content: Had a terriable experience.First problem. It is loaded with intrusive adds to include the lock screen. There's an option to pay $15 to remove adds. That's only for the lock screen there are still all over once you get past lock screen.Second problem.You can't customize anything. Lock screen back ground, nothing. Even if you pay to remove the adds.Third problem.It's slow and doesn't play a lot of videos on websites such as ABC or NBC for shows like SNL.Fourth problem.It wouldn't charge past 80 percent when it would charge. I had to send it back and told them to keep it.

Reviews.Title: Customer Service Was Bad
Reviews.Author: Norman T. Franklin
Reviews.Content: Worked GREAT until Oct. 20th, 2013.  Would not download any games but everything else worked fine.  After several hours on phone with techs they decided to replace it.  The new one did the same thing...would take several days to download a game and then get an error message.  Again spent several hours on the phone with techs over three days.  I was disconnected twice while being transferred. Got to the point again of returning and replacing kindle when I got transferred to a tech in APPS Store.  He wanted to go through the whole troubleshooting process again after being on the phone for over 2 hrs prior.  He was rude and had a superior attitude after I could not keep up with him and what he wanted me to do.  Finally I told him I wanted to return the kindle completely for a refund.During all of this we did talk to one customer service lady, Mary Ann, and she was wonderful.  Thank you Mary Ann.My advice is to make sure you buy the extended warranty and be ready to deal with some horrible customer service.

Reviews.Title: Do Not Waste Your Money
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: Keeps FreezingI have had to return 3 times and am still without a working device. It freezes, screen flickers, and now the newest one will not hold  a charge.

Reviews.Title: I can't put it down!
Reviews.Author: Sandy C.
Reviews.Content: I had an older Kindle that needed to be replaced, so I researched iPads, Windows tablets, and other options, but ultimately decided that my needs suited the Kindle.  I upgraded to the smaller model with less power and without 4G.  Once it arrived, I loved it and also realized I couldn't ever put it down, so I immediately upgraded to the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" 4G LTE Wireless.  It is far more than I ever imagined, and I don't know how I've lived without it so far.  I LOVE, LOVE, LOVE my new Kindle.

Reviews.Title: Good if you never want anything but Amazon stuff
Reviews.Author: Dudley's Dad
Reviews.Content: I have the original 7" Fire and an 8.9" Fire HD and have had much experience with both.  The physical construction of both is quite good, although I find the smaller Fire much easier to move around with, and I like its implementation of the Starter page for the Web browser infinitely better than that of the HD, which sticks one with a bunch of crappy "Selected" sites that apparently pay Amazon to stick links on your screen that you have zero control over, and a bunch more of "Trending" stuff that I would love to disable. I would really like to have MY Selected sites (favorites) displayed on screen in lieu of Amazon's, and perhaps more of my recent history.  However, two thirds of the screen is consumed by the Amazon-imposed links.  I also miss the externally viewable LED indication of "Fully Charged/Charging" status...if the HD is turned off, I have to turn it on to see if it is charged, which seems a bit regressive in terms of human design.  However, the addition of an external volume control with the HD implementation is quite helpful.  As for the power button, I like the Fire's better because of instant feedback, where with the HD I just have to wait to see if I depressed it far enough.  That a minor annoyance, at most, but one designers may want to look at in the future,As I noted, the physical quality of the units is excellent, so my beefs are with the software/firmware limitations.  My major grouse is the intentional blocking of apps that run fine on other Androids, but apparently Amazon has crippled their version so that it will accept only apps obtained via Amazon.  Worse yet, some apps that would run on the Fire won't run on the Fire HD.  Let me state now that if one is technically proficient and determined, one can often "sideload" apps not approved by Amazon which work fine...in fact, I routinely use a browser on my HD that I find more responsive than Amazon's and it displays what I want displayed, not what Amazon selects for me, plus I can watch webcasts and similar videos which apparently Amazon hasn't figured out how to handle since Adobe refused to support Flash Player on Android. I understand the desire to control what is loaded, but some of their protection is clearly self-serving, and not about users at all (at least in my opinion).  So here is the important take-away from this:  If you are willing to live exclusively in a world where Amazon dictates what is available to you, you'll love the unit.  Otherwise, get ready to live without some really useful apps or to take the risk of running them down on the net and side-loading them (some of which can indeed booger up your system).By the way, for those grousing about the power charging unit not being included, that is clear in the material and ordering process. Since some people already have several adequate charging modules, and since Amazon cuts you a deal when you order if you don't already have one, that's just not a legitimate gripe!  After all, why should those who don't need a charger have to buy one anyway?However, when one pays to avoid advertising content, only to have it imposed on the start page of the browser in terms of "Selected" internet sites not controlled by the user, I feel that I have been had.  However, as stated above, I don't necessarily use their browser that much anyway, so what the heck!  It is just so dishonest!If I buy another tablet, it will absolutely be a tablet upon which I can load whatever I want to load so long as it is written for Android, so it will likely not be another Amazon product, unless they alter course considerably.  Of course, they make their choices, and we all have to ultimately make ours.  Just be fully informed, check out some online demo's or evaluations and/or check out a friend's before you buy.

Reviews.Title: product is great.......app selection is for children.
Reviews.Author: taw
Reviews.Content: I've been a huge amazon fan for a long time. So when I was looking around for a tablet or reader my first thought obviously went to amazon.  The quality of the actual kindle is great. And I had been aware before I purchased it that I wouldn't have access to google play apps(which seems very odd since my google phone goes out of its way to promote amazon). That said I expected amazon to have at least comparable app's. Much to my surprise I can't get my local bank app,  groupon which has my local discounts, nor can I  get my local news app just to name a few. Very disappointed in the app selection offered, every time I open the page it looks like it's set up for a 6 or 8 year old.I also have a lot of issues with connectivity to WiFi even at home. I'll be able to connect to my laptop but not to my kindle. If you want the kindle to read it's a great option, but if you want more think about going with an android full operating system tablet. I will still shop with Amazon because the products and service are above average. I however can't say that I will push to purchase a direct Amazon product again.

Reviews.Title: I can't believe after all of the research that I did, I don't like it.
Reviews.Author: B. Elmore
Reviews.Content: I sew a lot, so I keep movies and tv shows streaming on my computer for entertainment. I'm also read a lot. I also buy a lot of music. All of these things have Amazon in common.  I am a good customer.  So since my computer was suffering under the weight of all of those downloaded files and since I was getting the blue screen of death about once a week, I decided to take action.I researched and looked for a solution.My thinking: if I could get a tablet that could take the Amazon content off my computer, I might be able to extend the life of my laptop.  I looked at the Microsoft Surface and the Amazon Kindle seriously. I read all of the reviews, I put out messages to friends who have one or the other, I asked questions.  In the end, mostly because of price and ties to Amazon, I opted to get the Kindle Fire HD 8.9".  Since most of my online activity includes Amazon, I thought it would be the better purchase.My first complaint is about the shipping service. I am a Prime customer. I deserve better shipping than what I got.  Now, I do have many of my Amazon purchases sent to a PO Box.  I know, how un-American of me, but I don't live in a sweet little neighborhood with mailboxes out front. I live in the wild west with directions to houses that go something like this: Go five miles out and take the only road that you see left. Go another 2.56 miles and when you see the bush on the left, turn right.  Now, the UPS driver that serves our area knows all of us. He knows where we live, he knows where we work, he knows our children and where they work. He knows if he can get down our road if it rains, he knows who our friends are and where he can leave it if our road is impassable.  Fed Ex sends a different driver almost every time. Packages get lost or left with the wrong person. No worries. They signed for it!!  Now, if you were me, would you have your expensive Kindle purchase sent to your house or would you go ahead and have it sent to your PO Box.  Most people can find the post office. Even FedEx.  My Kindle sat at the FedEX facility in a large city in my state for 36 hours!!!  There is no excuse for that.  The post office does have expedited shipping, why can't Amazon use that?  Or let me have the choice between UPS and FedEX on everything that I purchase. That would be great and worth the $79 that I spend every year to enjoy Prime shipping.Right out of the box, I could have used a manual.  I'm not stupid and I'm not of the "no tech" generation.  I'm of the "it's passing me by" generation.  The little iphone sized card called "Getting Started" isn't very informative. I found the on/off button and the volume.  I found the USB charger outlet thing. That mini USB connection feels so fragile. I miss the big ones. They at least felt like you could plug it in and not be damaging it.  The cord and the connector are stiff and I'm really worried that I'll mess those pins up when I plug it in.  I don't care for fragile things.  I like things with a more substantial feel.So, I finally get my Kindle.  Being so rural, I admit that my internet options are limited. But, I chatted online with someone from Amazon about the Kindle and the possibility that the internet wouldn't work.  It does work, but it doesn't work like Amazon said it would. I said that I have DSL. I didn't hide anything. Internet reception is just ok.  If you live in a really rural area and you have to rely on DSL, it is going to be slow.  The Kindle will stream a little less well than streaming on your computer. It won't get better. You've been warned.Next, I have had a few electronic devices. I was a technology geek for awhile, but just got tired of trying to keep up. So, I know some things and haven't a clue about others.  Here is something I do know. Screens need to be calibrated.  If Kindle has a way to calibrate screens, I haven't found it.  Another good topic for a manual.  The reason I say this is because when I try to move a book off of my device or from the carousel, I'm supposed to be able to put my finger on the image and hold. After holding, a menu pops up and says, "remove from device, or carousel" depending upon which screen you are in.  This is the most frustrating procedure!! Six, eight times I placed my finger and hold and the image just shivers and there is no menu.  And typing a help message to the Kindle crew was a disaster. The space bar wouldn't engage and if I wanted to move the cursor, I couldn't move it with a key, I had to place my finger on the message in the approximate position and  hold. It took me 30 minutes to type a simple help message of 5 lines.  The screen needs to be calibrated.Next, my audible books didn't transfer.  I had my audible account long before Amazon bought them, so my passwords were not synced.  Last night, when I tried to use the help, I got a "contact us" (the awful email). This morning when I looked I got an explanation.  I changed my audible account in order to use my Amazon credentials.  Still nothing. There is no way, that I can find, that will let my Kindle know that I've made the changes.  Help search was no help and this would be a good time for a manual.  I still have had no word from the help team at Amazon.  I also had trouble with my email account, but that did work itself our this morning.Finally, as I'm checking out all of the features, I went into books.  I downloaded several books and went exploring.  I went into my ESV Bible hoping that I could take my Kindle to church (larger fonts).  I could not figure out how to move around in the book.  Once you are in it, any book, all of the options, like the back arrow and the home button disappear.  Okay, maybe you access those buttons like the settings, you pull down with your finger from the top, right? No.  I completely stumbled on tapping the book to get the options back.  Manual. Or at least another little iphone sized card with helpful hints.  Good Grief.By this time, I'm pretty frustrated. I'm happy that I saved my boxes and that I opened everything carefully.After sleeping on it, I got up this morning to take another look. I did get my email account on, but I still don't have access to my Audible account. I can access Prime Instant video and it will stream. Until the buffer is full, it pauses about every 30 seconds.  I pause at the beginning and then once it buffers, I watch.  But that dual antenna thing doesn't work in rural areas.  That was the main question that I asked, and I always got the same answer: If you can stream on your computer, you can stream on a Kindle. True, but you neglected to mention that it doesn't stream AS WELL.What do I like?The picture and the video are good.The sound is good.I like the fact that I can move content from Kindle to Cloud and back again.  That feature on the PC versions of Kindle and Unbox would have been very helpful and I wouldn't have found myself in that original predicament.  Anyway, I'm glad to have that ability. That is probably THE reason that I won't return this to Amazon.The core stuff that the Kindle is meant to do...works.I uninstalled Unbox off of my computer this morning and regained 220 GB of space. My computer already runs a little better.Bottom line: After taking some time with the Kindle Fire, I'll keep it.  I think that it will do what I wanted it to do. It will take over my Amazon content. I can do my browsing on it. I don't go that many places.  I can't watch hulu because I don't have a hulu plus membership and I can't watch anything on CBS, but I can still do that on my computer.  I'm going to reserve judgement about whether I'd buy the Kindle again. Maybe in time, I'll love it or at least like it better.`

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire great when it works
Reviews.Author: judith wallace
Reviews.Content: I was very excited when I got my first kindle as a gift from my husband. Three weeks later it just quit working. Would not turn on or recharge. After talking to a customer rep. I was sent a new Kindle and I returned the one not. working. The new one that the company sent me worked fine until last Thrusday. My husband and myself were playing Dragon Gem on it. Later on in the evening, I turned it on and went to Facebook to see if my Brother was on line. He was not, so when I closed out Facebook to go back to games, the screen went black and I HAVE NOT been able to get it to turn on. This morning I tried and all that came up was a picture of the battery showing it needed charging. The Kindle has been charging over night and all day yesterday. I really enjoy my kindle, but this is the second one that has quit working on me. I have babied both of these because I know what was paid for them. I would like for the company to replace this one also, or send me my money back. I really enjoyed the Kindle WHEN it worked and love the games I have loaded on it. Thank you, Judy Wallace

Reviews.Title: It really is a great product.
Reviews.Author: NJGirl
Reviews.Content: For the money, this tablet is fabulous. Other "big name" tablets may seem to have all the glamor, but honestly this works JUST as well. It's easy to use and it has a ton of apps. I purchased a cover and bluetooth keyboard from amazon.com for it too for $30 and it really is one of the best purchases I've ever made. And since it works on the android system its charger is android so you can interchange them with your cellphone if you have an android.

Reviews.Title: Not Quite Ready For Prime Time
Reviews.Author: Eric Garlepp "EEG"
Reviews.Content: Basically I had 4 different Kindle HD 8.9" fire's sent to me.  Each with a different hardware issue.  I really, really wanted it to work especially since i bought my son a 7" one and i have all the Amazon services.  But it was not to be, the first one had a problematic screen with a line through it after a day or 2 or very lite usage. The second one came and would not charge at all, i tried a few different chargers including the extra one i bought.  The third one, half the screen went black after using it for 3 hours and it would not charge and the fourth had charging issues as well. I gave ti 2 stars instead of 1 was because when it works it works well, but i can't deal with hardware issues especially when it is a gift for my wife. My sons 7" is working fine, i just bought my wife a refurbished iPad and will wait till they come out with the next iteration of hardware.  Come on Amazon, i have all your services and want to invest in your ecosystem, i just can't have spotty hardware.

Reviews.Title: Amazon Customer Service - Fantastic!!!
Reviews.Author: E. Schroder
Reviews.Content: I have not received my Kindle Fire HD 8.9 yet....  I called (or actually they called me at my request) today at 11 am to tell them that my original Kindle Fire (from 11/11 when they first came out) would not charge anymore.  We went through a few 'fix-it' things and both agreed that it was not going to charge no matter what.  So - I was offered some very nice deals (for a device that was well out of warranty..) and chose the one to get a significant dollar amount ($100) off of a Fire HD 8.9.  Because I am a Prime member they said that I would get it in two days.  Thinking that I would have withdrawals for at least one day, I used up the remaining battery power on my beloved Fire.  But guess what!?!?!  I just got an email saying that my new Fire would be here tomorrow!!!! I am delighted! People may complain about Amazon not including the charger (and I agree with the complaints) but you cannot beat 24-30 hour delivery on an significantly discounted item.  I realize that about 2 people will read this review - but I had to write it.  It is SO easy to complain about bad service, but not enough people talk about good service.

Reviews.Title: uncomparable picture quality!
Reviews.Author: md garrett
Reviews.Content: I highly recommend this product to any/all other tablets on the market.  You simply cannot purchase a tablet with better picture quality for the price than this item.  I splurged and got the 32gb with no advertisements and LOVE IT!

Reviews.Title: after comparing iPad4 and nexus 10 , kindle fire 89 wins
Reviews.Author: Falguni Harish Patel
Reviews.Content: one of the best and fastest tablets of 2012.  most value for your money, the fastest, and best sound quality

Reviews.Title: Love. Love.  Love my new Kindle!!!!!
Reviews.Author: Roslyn Nelson
Reviews.Content: I am still learning how to use it. But I love it and I know I am going to use it for many years. I am so glad I waited for the HD.... Don't hesitate if you have been thinking about getting one, get one on Amazon....

Reviews.Title: Supercalifragilisticexpialidociou
Reviews.Author: Jade Kerrion
Reviews.Content: The best thing about it-the video and sound quality: The Kindle Fire HD 8.9″ is supercalifragilisticexpialidocious! Yes, I love it (the obvious caveat being that I'm clearly prejudiced, so take this review for what it's worth.)  I watched a movie on Amazon Prime yesterday on my new Fire HD and peeked over my husband's shoulder while he watched an Amazon Prime movie on his iPad. No contest. The Fire HD left the iPad in the dust with video and sound quality. In fact, it won so convincingly that I'm not sure how much use I'll have of my Fire HD in the future since my husband will be "borrowing" it frequently (that's why I keep buying Kindles...mine keep getting purloined by family members.)Storage space: I opted for 32GB, after being consistently frustrated by running up against the 8GB limit on my Kindle Fire (1st gen.) After loading all my apps, music, and desired books, I found myself with 26+GB to spare. (I'd caveat this by saying I only loaded my preferred music, about 300+ songs, and a small selection of my favorite books...after all, I do most of my reading on my Kindle Paperwhite.) If you tend to be selective about the material you put on your Kindle, you may be able to get by on 16GB. If, however, you intend to load lots of videos, 32GB would be the way to go.Wi-Fi vs Wi-Fi + 4G LTE: I opted for Wi-Fi only, in part because the cost of the 4G LTE comes up to about $130. You do get a great deal from AT&T; in the first year and can receive 250MB per month for 12 months for just $50, which is a steal. Unfortunately, after the first year, AT&T;'s typical data rates will apply, which will run about $50 a month for its cheapest package. I would never subscribe for a data package at that rate and I didn't think that paying $180 for just one year of 4G LTE service would be worth it, so I opted for Wi-Fi only. No regrets there. My husband's two iPads (technically, one is my son's) have never needed 4G service either. If, in an emergency, we need 4G access, well, that's what the iPhone is for (not that you can trust its map anymore, but that's a separate issue...)Kindle FreeTime: I don't intend to let my kids use my new Kindle (brave words, hah! Check back with me in a month) but I did experiment with the Kindle FreeTime function, which allows parents to control which apps/books/videos their child gets to use (and you can customize for each child) as well as control the amount of time they get to spend on the Kindle in total, or for each category of product. For example, you can allow them unlimited time with books, a half hour with videos, and a half hour with apps. As a parent, let me say that this is AMAZING. Amazon has also put out Kindle FreeTime Unlimited, a subscription-based service that gives children access to a wide range of videos, books, and apps appropriate to their age for a fairly reasonable price ($2.99 a month per child for an Amazon Prime member.) That seems like a pretty good deal to me.Special offers or no special offers: I paid an extra $15 to have a Kindle without special offers. My Kindle Fire will likely be utilized by children and I didn't want to deal with finding out that my child accidentally purchased a $599 botox session out in California. Amazon really does need to fix its one-click purchasing. I'd like some serious password protection on that ability.Minor gripes: My only real grip is the lack of ability to catalog my books. I think this reason is at least partially responsible for my utilizing a separate Kindle Paperwhite for my primary reading tool (I need reasons to justify my five Kindles, after all). I like my books neatly categorized. There is no such functionality on the Kindle Fire, and my obsessive-compulsive streak gets all twitchy down my spine.In summary, the Kindle Fire HD 8.9″ is a fantastic quality compared to its counterparts in Apple, and you get it for an amazingly low price. Amazon makes it up on accessories...

Reviews.Title: Wow, it is more than a Tablet, it is a Mini Super Computer
Reviews.Author: Ronald Kasozi "Baby Franklin"
Reviews.Content: I have just received my Kindle Fire. Wow, it is really great-Great speeds, clear crystal picture, clear audio sounds and makes you read your book with perfect letters. Just downloads everything pretty fast, no eye pain in viewing videos or in reading books evening when near your eyes, easy to use and learn-took me just minutes to learn the various menus and oh it has a number of my interesting applications-Facebook, twitter, Skype easily connected. With Amazon prime, the sky is the limit on its functions and usefulness. I had wanted an Ipad, but I have no regrets. Thank you Amazon, you have won one customer from the Apple loyal family.

Reviews.Title: Love it!
Reviews.Author: Leanne K. Hust
Reviews.Content: Perfect size for watching movies!  Great sound and screen!  The kids love playing games on it.  It is the perfect size for reading books. I looked for a long time and didn't want to spend the extra money on an IPAD.  Saved some money and I am happy.

Reviews.Title: Great Product! But I wish I would have waited two weeks for the extra $50 off
Reviews.Author: Kelly Bookhultz
Reviews.Content: The sceen is great with great viewing angles.  Not too big or too small.  Very well made like the IPad. Works great with Public Library and Book Bub.  Wifi works great anywhere in our house and the downloads are fast with FIOS service.  The ads are not bothersome on the screen saver, so save yourself the $15. I just can't believe they put this on sale now for $50 off so soon after I bought it.

Reviews.Title: A Definite Improvemment over the first Kindle FIRE
Reviews.Author: Chris M
Reviews.Content: The HD picture and the stereo sound, the thinner screen and the new tab for photos are all great improvements for the price. My only disappointment is the charging port. My first Kindle was very difficult to charge unless I stood it up in a particular way. I thought with the new design this problem would be eliminated. Although, it is better I have still had trouble getting the charging cable to connect to the port

Reviews.Title: Awesome device
Reviews.Author: Reena R Harris
Reviews.Content: So glad I didn't get the mini iPad! Just bummed that it won't play Flash. Otherwise great purchase! Resolution is fantastic.

Reviews.Title: Awesome!
Reviews.Author: Lollipopgestappo
Reviews.Content: I know a lot of people are not happy or so it would seem with the Kindle Fire HD, however as a first time kindle owner I LOVE IT. To me it has very easy to use interface, typing is just as easy though a bit larger on the buttons then what I am used to from my smart phone.(Will defintely have to get a stylus to make it a tad easier) Surfing the web was fine. I crochet and recently started learning how to knook. Which is a way of knitting with a crochet hook, and I was able to use my Fire to go to the Leisure Arts website and watch the how to videos they have. All in all I think this was very worth the money!

Reviews.Title: Love, love, love it!!
Reviews.Author: karent
Reviews.Content: I absolutely love my new kindle fire HD!  My husband has had an ipad since May and it was great, but the kindle is much faster and the picture is incredible!!  I have owned a kindle for several years and read almost constantly in my spare time, but the new kindle fire allows me to do so much more!  I would highly recomend it!  The only thing it doesnt have that the ipad has is the camera, but we don't use the ipad to take pictures anyway.

Reviews.Title: I luv my Kindle
Reviews.Author: Russ H.
Reviews.Content: I bought the Kindle Fire HD for my wife as a birthday gift. Big problem. I can't get her to put it down. It was easy to set up, connected to my router WiFi, set up her gmail and off she went, shopping for holders, screen protector and MORE books.Looks like I will have to buy one for myself.

Reviews.Title: Fun to use!
Reviews.Author: S. Fergason
Reviews.Content: You can do almost anything on the Kindle you can on a pad.  I don't like that the camera is only usable for what is facing the screen.  If you have the camera app you can't take a picture of someone on the other side of the Kindle. That goes for the video as well.  I really don't like that.  Other than that it is easy to navigate.  The picture and sound quality are great.  I am not a computer novice by any means so this suits me greatly.

Reviews.Title: Great product minor complaint
Reviews.Author: Bob Harte
Reviews.Content: We are now on our 8th Kindle the last two a Paperwhite for my wife  which she loves) and the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 for myself.  Over all I would give this product a five star plus rating except for one minor flaw. we purchased the std case and love it, that is until I try to fold it back to rest on a table and find I can't  because the charging cable is coming out of the bottom (when folded back) of the kfire and it interferes with the table. Something to fix in the next generation.

Reviews.Title: Should be TWO reviews
Reviews.Author: Walter E. Obrien "Dogjudge"
Reviews.Content: From my perspective there should be two reviews of the Kindle Fire HD. One for those people who have never owned a Kindle Fire and one for those people who have.I've owned the original Kindle, a Kindle Fire and now the Kindle Fire HD.For those who have never owned a Kindle Fire. You are going to be extremely happy with your purchase whether you are upgrading from a Kindle, or if you have never owned a product such as this before. You are going to love this. Books, movies, TV, Music, etc. is second to none. My wife has an iPad and the graphics are just as good, if not better.The only thing that I would complain about, and this relates to any item where you use the screen to type, I simply don't like it. My iPhone is probably the worst. At least on the Kindle Fire HD, you have the ability to turn the unit to landscape mode and get a bigger keyboard.For those who have a Kindle Fire. You are going to have to ask yourself it the larger screen is worth it. Yes, the graphics are better. Yes, the screen is brighter. Amazon says that this screen is not as reflective. Perhaps it's me, but I didn't find it all that noticeable a difference. Sound from the speakers and through earphones (Bose) are definitely a step up.I've never had a problem with my Kindle Fire viewing movies, etc., so the best that I can is that the Kindle Fire HD is better, or worse. It's the same.Overall, I'm happy I upgraded.

Reviews.Title: Not a fan of Silk bit overall good price and quality
Reviews.Author: snocaps231 "Kindle Touch 3G, Kindle Fire HD 8.9"
Reviews.Content: I have owned a few tablets in the past: iPad 1, iPad 2, Galaxy Tab 2 7.0 and my KFHD 8.9 will probably rank 2nd to my old iPad 2 but then again, I spent $699 on that. Instead of repeating a long drawn out review, I rated my kfhd 4 due to Silk. I dont know if its just mine or if its a glitch but I tend to get a lot of tab stopped working would you like to recover previous tabs. I dont lose my pages but the fact I continue receiving the error troubles me. I do miss Chrome and maybe still getting use to this Silk, but it just does not seem as stable.Overall, great device. Planet Amazon is complete.

Reviews.Title: Awesome Tablet!!!
Reviews.Author: Kristina
Reviews.Content: I've had my new Kindle Fire HD for three whole days now and I love it. My hubby bought it for my B-Day and it seems like he's used it more than me. Compared to similar tablets, this one is lighter, slick, brighter resolution, extremely easy to use and the sound/speakers are the best! I love the home screen and how it tracks all of the recent things and or places you've visited and or worked on. I have Amazon Prime and love how easy it is to view free movies, read books/ magazines and all the Apps available. The x-ray addition while you are viewing movies is a neat feature, especially when you want to know who the actors are and a little more about them. I also like how you can set different profiles for my children and be able to monitor/control what they do and for how long, etc. The battery will last you half a day if you're constantly using it. I would have loved to see a rear facing camera as well. There is just so much to this tablet that I have yet to figure out. So far,i am extremely satisfied with my new Kindle. This is the best product by far for the $$$ you pay and for what you get. I have already customized my Kindle to fit my style with a new Pink(Fuchsia) Amazon cover and Stylus  :-)

Reviews.Title: I'm in love...
Reviews.Author: Jennifer E. Monroy "Mom of 4"
Reviews.Content: I just received my Kindle Fire last week, and I can't put it down.  I stream all kinds of video from Amazon, and the display/sound quality are fantastic.  I love the touch screen.  It feels great!  Web browsing is easy and fast.  I just need to figure out how to sync the Kindle calendar with the calendar on my phone.  Other than that, I love my Kindle Fire!

Reviews.Title: Totally not what I understood it to be
Reviews.Author: Lawrence Ballesteros
Reviews.Content: I bought the Kindle to take to Europe to check e-mails, do internet searches and such.  It's supposed magical ability to snoop out wireless where-ever available is a total fallacy.  I could not access my internet so then my e-mail and internet searches were totally non-existent.  It's supposed great camera, I found out to my dismay does not take pictures.  I am so angry at this product I cannot be objective about it, I have never been so disappointed by an Amazon.com purchase in my history with this company.  It totally stressed out what should have been an exciting adventure.  I will not miss an opportunity to share my negative experience with anyone considering purchasing the Kindle Fire.  I want my money back, Thank you.

Reviews.Title: Great tablet with stunning display
Reviews.Author: The Kurgan
Reviews.Content: My thoughts on the tablet:Display- As has been commented many times, the display is stunning, a HUGE selling pointSound- You can comfortably watch movies or TV without using headphones. Granted, I turn up the volume all the way, but there is zero distortion and the quality of the sound is quite highBattery indicator- I read a lot of reviews before I bought this and many complained there was no battery charge indicator on the tablet. This was obviously corrected by Amazon before I got my tablet because there most certainly IS a battery charging indicator. Granted, there is no light indicator to show when fully charged, but this is not needed.The OS- Many complaints focused on this being a locked down version of Android, can't customize, blah blah. It's true, it is "locked down", but everyone should bear in mind so is the IPAD and more so than this tablet. Many complained there was a software glitch in the carousel where you could not remove items, this has obviously been fixed because it works perfectly. In general, I like the carousel and the general operation of the OS. It's super fast and super easy, between the favorites star and the carousel you have pretty much everything you needThe app store- The app store is very good, easy to navigate and purchase. True, they don't have everything, but they have a LOT of thingsThe browser- I had no issues at all with the stock browser, but thought I'd pass this on. There were a great many people saying to use the "Dolphin" browser because it was supposed to be a great browser and also because it supported flash so you could work around the "no flash" issue. There were tons of remarks about having to "sideload" Dolphin and about a million different instructions on doing so. Forget all that. You don't need to do that. You can just download an alternate app store called "good e reader", there are excellent instructions on youtube, not that it's really needed, you literally have to change one setting and then you can download it normally, there is nothing strange or exotic required. Once you have this app store, IT has the Dolphin HD browser, flash, and probably a ton of other stuff, I haven't downloaded much else. The point is, you can just download from this appstore, there is no "sideloading" shennanigans needed and have the Dolphin Browser. I will say, the Dolphin browser DOES live up to its billing, it's fantastic, I'm glad I downloaded itAmazon ecosystem- amazing, far better than apple's in every regard except number of apps. The music is far superior as are the video offerings. I have watched a bunch of free stuff with my prime membership and it works flawlessly. Shopping directly from amazon for anything else on the planet is super convenient and works flawlesslySize/Shape compared to full sized IPAD: The 8.9 is almost identical to IPAD in Height. The difference is really in the width, the fire HD is narrower than the IPAD, which mostly accounts for it's reduced spec of 8.9 as compared to 9.9. What this really amounts to is the IPAD is much more of a square shape, it's almost like a 4:3 aspect ratio TV. The Fire HD is shaped much more like a modern TV or computer monitor, with a 16:9 ratio. One benefit besides better movie and TV shape that I did not expect is that if you turn the tablet into a "portrait" orientation to type, you can type very quickly with both thumbs just like a cellphone.

Reviews.Title: update:  charging issues
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: This is an entertainment device, not a computer tablet, unless you willing to root.  Got mine last night, played around with it and went to bed.  I'm now typing this review on my 10.1 Acer, its what I reached for this morning, not the Fire.The Google play store, home screen, access to multiple browsers, etc, all confirm the Iconia tablet  is a mini-computer.The Fire has a beautiful display and great sound.  It will be handy when I go to the gym and travel as a way to pass the time.  Wonderful as a reader, the text is incredible.  The layout and ads all suggest, however, that it is meant as a marketing device, profit tool, not a portable pc.I suspect a lot of the unease with using this device, from the critics, is psychological...it's true, somehow it doesn't feel like "mine".BTW, the on/off button is ridiculous, way too flat.  First Generation power button was much easier to find.If I could only have one, it would the Acer...same price, but with a larger screen.  Since my husband uses the tablet at home as well, we will switch back and forth and have the best of both.Otherwise I would return it.Update:  2/2:  charging issues...I've tried all the usual strategies and called Amazon and they are sending a replacement.  Why the hell does the kindle have so many charging problems?  Acer tab has been chugging along with no battery issues whatsoever, and the charger lasts so much longer.  Something to be said for reliability...

Reviews.Title: Great but...
Reviews.Author: Sharon Eagle
Reviews.Content: I really like my new Kindle and use it quite a bit. However there are 3 things that REALLY bug me about it. 1. The on/off button needs to be relocated or protected somehow. Located where it is, it is WAY to easy to accidentally hit it and turn the Kindle off while I'm using it. Just watching a 3 hr movie I accidently turned it off at least 6 times. Fortunately it was easy it hit "resume" when I turned it back on and continue with my movie. 2. The touch feature is often unresponsive. it is annoying to have to repeatedly touch things over and over to try to get them to respond. 3. Advertisements show up WAY TOO OFTEN and interrupt what I'm doing. I paid a big chunk of money to use and play with my new Kindle, not to deal with a continual barrage of advertisements. If I knew then, what I know now, I'd probably think twice about buying it, for this reason.If the next version addresses and fixes these 3 problems then I'd gladly give it 5 stars.

Reviews.Title: more trouble than worth?  frustrated trying to get set up.
Reviews.Author: DianaInTheD
Reviews.Content: My overwhelming reaction has been frustration.  I've had Apple products and Android products, and I've never struggled so much.  My main complaints:1.  No Gmail app.  I use Gmail on my phone and on my laptop.  Not being able to use it here, and being limited to a clunky email program is very frustrating.2.  No Google Play.  After spending time trying to work with the Amazon Cloud Player, I bailed - the thought of paying for what I was getting free on Google Play wasn't sitting well with me.  I was able to get my music transferred over to the Kindle Fire via USB, but for some reason some of the album artwork covers aren't displaying.  They display fine in iTunes and in Google Play, but not here.  I have no idea if something isn't embedded properly, but........  somehow it all magically worked in Google Play and iTunes.  So, i'm annoyed that I'm spending time trying to figure out what's wrong with 500 of my 3500 music files.  It's important to figure out, because the music display is primarily the album covers - having tons of matching grey ones is not helpful3.  Clunky music interface.  There's no way to play by genre.  Your only options are playlists/artists/albums/songs.  Do I really have to make a playlist for each genre?  Also, the search capability is poor, it's hard to maneuver around even if you know exactly what you're trying to play.  Because I used the USB to transfer my music, I have no playlists transferred, so i have to recreate painfully on the device.  Also because I'm not paying for the cloud, I can't do my playlists on a laptop and transfer them.  Again, it's frustrating because none of these are issues on Google Play. I'm finding I'm pulling out my phone and playing music on my phone 'cause it's easier to maneuver.4.  No categories/folders in the books area.  I am heavily dependent on that on my Kindle Touch to sort into different categories.  Here, I'm supposed to buy another app that doesn't work seamlessly with the Kindle Fire?  And again, we've had the concept of organizing electronic things into folders since DOS.  Really, Amazon?  You can't add a folders capability?5.  No Google Drive.  Same with the email and music - I'm cut off from something I rely on quite a bit.I am an Amazon Prime member.  I've enjoyed the free streaming - that's beautiful.  I really like Amazon - but this is very frustrating.  If I can figure out a way to make all of this work, I think I'll be fine.  It's just the initial setup is way more painful than I expected.  I'm unsure if I want to keep right now.

Reviews.Title: A nice little device
Reviews.Author: Matthew Erler
Reviews.Content: I've had my Kindle for a week and it's been generally good so far. My uses for it:1.  Reading my comic book collection.2.  Reading books purchased from Amazon.3.  Reading ebooks checked out from my local library.4.  Looking up people/movies on IMDB.5.  Watching move trailers.Pros:  1. Price.  Especially today with the $50 discount.  I didn't get it when I originally ordered it 3 weeks ago but customer support gave it to me anyway when I asked for it.  2.  Screen quality.  It's very nice.  video is clear.  Images are sharp.  Refresh rate is good.  3.  Sound is good for two little speakers.  I use a wireless bluetooth Plantronics BackBeat 903+ Headset when I watch movies.  Sound is great then.  4.  Router connectivity.  The Kindle found my Cisco-Linksys E2000 Advanced Wireless-N Router right away.Cons:  1.  The power button is hard to find with my finger.  That's not a big deal though.  I only turn it off at night.  2.  It insists on adding apps/doc that I open to the carousel.  I don't want it to do that because I don't want seldom used apps/docs to clutter up the carousel.  3.  DRM has been an issue.  I've purchased several books but couldn't open them due to DRM.  That's frustrating because reading books is what this thing is for and anything purchased from Amazon should work on Amazon's tablet IMHO.  I returned them without a problem.  4.  App selection is limited in Amazon's store.  5.  Browser is buggy.Work arounds: 1.  I install apps from another app store to work around Amazon's limited selection.  I use 1Mobile Market.2.  I've installed an alternate browser, Dolphin, from 1Mobile Market and it works great.

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire 8.9" HD
Reviews.Author: Chris
Reviews.Content: Just a starter observation...................delivery from time of shipment to receiving was snail slow,so if you want it quick eat the cost and pay the extra,I was in no rush but just advising those who need the item for a gift quick.  This is my second Kindle,I dont use them personally but my wife is an avid reader loves chatting with friends on Facebook type sites so this particular tablet works well for her.............and it is that,a Tablet,has everything she needs,I found she favours this over the laptop as it is fast when going from site to site so is a good multi tasking tool,as with anything I buy i like to buy the accesories for an item,the fast charger is really a good buy as was the Amazon Kindle cover,can recommend the HDMI lead too I bought 2 and have them in 2 TV's so movies etc can be watched in either room.  The Kindle was VERY FAST SETUP,transferred everything from the 1st kindle so nothing was lost.Exceptionally clear screen,very responsive screen and seems to work quickly without issue on anything,admittedly this is early days so will update as time goes on.....................I am not a computer whiz if it turns on great,if it doesnt,its broke.Sorry if this review is unhelpful to some,I feel it was a worthwhile purchase worth the $$$$$,cant really comment on the speakers as it plays thru a bluetooth speaker which by the way is awesome.March 2013...........updating..........the cloud player feature for music is great,downloaded alot of my wifes music cd's to the cloud then sent to her Kindle so lots of music to listen to,micro hdmi plugged into back of TV plays movies great too,predominatley purchsed as a reader she has fast learned alot about it,emails web etc all work flawlessley,havent had any problems so far,only thing i noted is books are sent to Kindle lightening fast,some apps may not appear for a few hours,not sure why but it happens on occasion.Fast charger is GREAT my wife uses this all day to read play games,surf the web,emails...........point being it holds a charge along time,no where near as much as the original kindle(days at a time) but can last couple of days between charge with alot of use.

Reviews.Title: Kindle Fire 8.9 Review- Good but problems with charging
Reviews.Author: Kindle Customer
Reviews.Content: I've been a great supporter of Amazon and their eco-system for years. I have a prime membership which I enjoy quite a bit and my wife and I have purchased numerous Kindle products over the years for ourselves and family members.I have been going back and forth for the last month on purchasing a new tablet with a HD screen. I was torn between the new Ipad, the Asus TF700 and the Kindle fire HD 8.9. On a side note I am heavily invested in Apple as well as I own several of there products including an Apple TV and earlier Ipad models, 1 and 2.In the end I picked the Kindle Fire HD 8.9 because of the beautiful screen and very attractive price. I went to Best Buy to purchase the Kindle only because I had a $50 gift card that I put towards the purchase price, otherwise I would have brought it from Amazon.I came home excited, opened the package and started to set up my new Kindle. The screen is stunning to say the least and it appeared to work much faster then the original Kindle Fire we brought last year. I knew I was going to enjoy my tablet.That is until I plugged it in to charge. I notice that the charge indicator kept turning green which meant it was charging, but then it would stop after a few minutes. I had a charger from our original Kindle Fire we were using and verified it worked with the other Kindles in our household. At one point it appeared the charge was holding so off I went to attend to other errands. When I came back the Kindle was at 17% charge, and the indicator was no longer showing green. I ended up getting another charger in the house and tried that one to no avail. I ended up buying the Kindle accelerated charger and that did not work as well, but it worked for our original Kindle fire. I gave up a little upset but I also understand these things happen to electronic products. I took the Kindle back to Best Buy which was a no fuss process and they took it back with no complaints. It was exchanged for a new Kindle Fire HD 8.9.I went home excited once again and went through the previous process of setting it up. Once done I plugged it into the Kindle charger we had brought and once again the indicator came on that it was charging. At least it was working. I came back about an hour later and saw that the indicator was off and the Kindle had not charged. I could not get the Kindle to charge no matter what I did.Frustrated, I drove once again to Best Buy and they tested it out and had the same outcome. They brought another Kindle Fire to me, but this time they allowed me to open it up in the store to make sure this one worked. Can you believe three different Kindle Fire HD, and all 3 had the same issue. At this point I gave up and ended up purchasing an Asus TF700, which up to this point has worked as advertised and whose screen is equally stunning.Again, I'm not naive to know things happen like this, but after 3 attempts it appears there is an issue because I have now seen other reviews describing the same issue. I love Amazon and our other Kindle products have work with no problem. Maybe next year I will attempt to buy one of these models after the kinks have been worked out.

Reviews.Title: Comcast email problems
Reviews.Author: Richard S. Scull "Slotdoc"
Reviews.Content: I would have given the Kindle Fire HD 8.9" tablet a 5-Star rating if it weren't for the email problems encountered with Comcast.  I'm completely satisfied with all the other features except email - which I consider one of, if not the most important functions of the internet.  After contacting customer service 4 times on this issue, they reluctantly devulged that the upgraded software version is probably not compatible (yet) with Comcast's email since the 8.9" tablet is so new (in other words - it was rushed into market). They have no idea when this problem will be addressed by their programmers...not my words - theirs. Here's the problem(s): Comcast email must be set-up manually on the Kindle HD.  After verifying all info with their tech support reps it seemed that the service worked OK once or twice, then it ceased to operate - it actually wiped itself clean from the Kindle upon startup.  When I went back into the email accounts area - Comcast was "gone" - and I had to go thru the set-up function again.  This happened several times; it failed to perform properly every day after "sleeping" for a while; usually not finding any mail when I had personally sent some from my other computers. By the way, I'm not new at this - I've been around computers for over 40 years and taught electronics in the Army. My temporary solution - I went into my Comcast email account and activated email "forwarding" to my Gmail account; then set-up my Gmail account on the Kindle HD.  If you decide to go this way, be sure to "keep a copy of emails" in your Comcast box so you can access them from your computer. Here's hoping Amazon makes this issue a priority - this is a Great Product!

Reviews.Title: Some improvements some things worse
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "Nathyn"
Reviews.Content: I had an original 7" fire and decided to get the new 8.9" HD.  There are some definite improvements to this device and some things were Amazon took steps backwards.The good:Screen looks much better.  Very sharp, very clear.Audio is great. Loudest on any tablet I've owned.Xray and read along with audiobooks is awesome.The bad:Power and volume buttons about the hardest to find and push. They're flush with the case and there's virtually no tactile indication that this is where you push or know when you've pushed it. Very annoying.  The power button issue makes me come close to returning it.Apps that used to run on the fire now need tablet versions and have to be rebought.The carousel is not as easy to use as on the original.I'm probably going to pay to get rid of ads.  I don't mind them on the paperwhite, but they feel horribly intrusive on the Fire.All in all, it's a solid tablet for the price, but there are issues that can be very annoying.

Reviews.Title: Bigger is Not Necessarily Better
Reviews.Author: Carol
Reviews.Content: I bought the 8.9 HD kindle, after having owned my first kindle fire for over a year. I was thinking it could be a substitute for a laptop. I was wrong it is just like the smaller kindle, but not "purse size" Yes, it is bigger, but not that much, as the border around the screen is an inch wide. I bought a small Bluetooth keyboard, and it works like a phone keyboard, but for someone like me who does not text frequently, the words often came up incomplete and if I made a typing error I would have to take time to edit. So now I basically have two reading devices, and I take the smaller one when I am going out. The bigger one works great, and I can get the same books I purchased on both at the same time, but I wish I had put the money on a laptop instead.

Reviews.Title: Beautiful Device - When it Works!
Reviews.Author: Jean M. Fortier
Reviews.Content: I am currently on my 3rd replacement Kindle in less than a year. When the Kindle works, it is a beautiful tablet; screen is great, speed is good, wifi reception is better than my husband's ipad. But Amazon has had replace my Kindle twice since I received it as gift late last April. The original one had problems with the volume control, on the second one the screen rotation would not work and it was locked in portrait mode. The third Kindle is still functioning but it has a lot of problems; the screen/device locks up for no good reason, it spontaneously shuts down, the screen does not always respond well when tapped. I will say that Amazon's customer service was professional,  responsive and replaced the defective devices with little or no hassle, but i would not recommend this product due to it's poor reliability.

Reviews.Title: Kindle fire hd 8 in review
Reviews.Author: Dawn Hinesley
Reviews.Content: I have had a number of problems with this version. I have the original kindle fire 7 inch and the new Kindle fire hdx 8.9. This particular item I have had to replace several times and I am still experiencing problems since replacing it twice. Would not recommend this version.

Reviews.Title: Junk
Reviews.Author: Tony Roby
Reviews.Content: I had to send it back 3 times. Device would just stop working. The last one I received is still glitchy, so I just bought my daughter another brand tablet that works. Don't waste your money or time on the Kindle!!!

Reviews.Title: I am not happy with this product
Reviews.Author: myrtle "DP"
Reviews.Content: I am on my 3rd Kindle Fire HD 8.9. It still does not work properly. I have done all the fixes Amazon has provided to no avail. The Kindle shuts off and  knocks me off the internet constantly. It gets really hot and freezes all the time. I don't even enjoy using it. If I had to do it over I would not purchase this again. I also have the 7 inch and I have no problems with it. I have asked Amazon for a credit  or a refund to use on something else but they refused. They just want to keep replacing it with a new one and it still doesn't work. So I guess I'm stuck with it.

Reviews.Title: Not working that well
Reviews.Author: Tajohnna ulmer
Reviews.Content: I say a one star cause it continue to shut off when I make a movement and that's starting to work my nerve the volume is not loud even tho it's on high

Reviews.Title: this product is very bad
Reviews.Author: xavi zhou
Reviews.Content: I use this product for few day but I discover many problem, The Battery life is to short, the front camera position deviation original position let me can not To accurately use it, the speaker play sounds has cracking voice and the most importance thing is the the touch screen has several especially dazzling light-spot. it's system is very slow and always has system halted.

Reviews.Title: Watch out IPad.
Reviews.Author: Book girl Eva
Reviews.Content: Don't get me wrong, Apple is a great company that makes great products, and I even own a IPod, but I have always found the IPad lacking for the amount of money it cost.  This tablet has not disappointed, and neither did my first gen fire, and the price cannot be beat.  I have told everyone that I know who is thinking of getting an IPad how much I love this device, and the kindle is the way to go.  I am a self proclaimed Amazon junkie, and rarely does a day go by that I do not visit this website.  This device goes to show that loyalty to a brand can be rewarded.  I will continue to show my loyalty to Amazon as long as they continue  to make great products like this for prices that regular people can afford.

Reviews.Title: Lacking in Apps
Reviews.Author: Rasheed Abdullah
Reviews.Content: I've had the Kindle Fire HD for about a year now.  I bought it as a viable and inexpensive alternative to the iPad (which I now have but more on that later).  I found it very intuitive and easy to use.  Aesthetically it is very nice, clean and durable, although I don't like the position of the power button nor the position of the power port.  Many times I've accidentally pressed the power button while moving the device and because of where the plug in for the power is I can't set up the Kindle landscape while it's charging.  Within the first week I had a problem with it.  I would be watching something or doing something and it would shutoff.  After referring to the forum I found out the problem was the case.  I called Amazon and their customer service was superb.  They sent me a new case right away with a return shipping label for the defective case and that fixed the problem.  They requested me to ship the defective case back by a certain date or I'd be charged for it ($50).  I actually missed the date which was about a week or two from the date I received it (I know, my fault).  But they still didn't charge me.  In fact, they sent me another notice giving me an extension.  I made the second date and everything was fine.  The Kindle Fire HD was great for watching videos, checking e-mails and reading ebooks.  It wasn't until I tried to watch programs via Comcast.net that I experienced my first problem.  Apparently, Kindle is missing an essential Adobe Flash Player for watching certain things via a web browser.  I think you can download it but I never looked into it much.  It was a bummer but not that big of a deal.  Well, that also affected Youtube viewing, for which there is a terrible app.  So, speaking of apps... that was the true killer.  Kindle has a terrible app selection and some of them don't work well.  Even though Kindle is an Android device it doesn't allow access to the same App market as other Droid devices (I read that it has something to do with not paying Google that extra money).  So Amazon has a slightly different version of a lot of the popular apps and/or it may not have the app at all.  That really sucked.  It was at that point I decided that I'd get the iPad instead.  In summary, I think the Kindle is great if 1.) you're an Amazon Prime member (as I am) or you peruse Amazon.com a lot (as I do) or 2.) you're using it for videos, books and e-mails.  The Kindle is not so good if you are a heavy app user or if you watch things via your browser.****UPDATE*****This is an update per one of the comments (or only comment).  The app I can think of right away that didn't work for me was the Despicable Me Minion game.  Another app I had issues with was Monopoly.  Besides the fact I couldn't play Monopoly with others in the house because they have Apple devices, it didn't work well for me.  I've yet to try the Netflix app, but the other standard apps seem to work fine.

Reviews.Title: I love it, but...
Reviews.Author: Craig Naset
Reviews.Content: Let me start by saying, "I have 3 Kindles". Someone gave me the original Kindle several years ago and I loved it. I talked about it so much that the same person gave me the Kindle Fire HD 7" when it came out. I loved it. Then I made the mistake of assuming that a Kindle could pretty much replace a laptop, and bought the Kindle Fire HD 8.9". Overall, I am happy with the purchase because it does what it does extremely well...but it doesn't do EVERYTHING!It does everything EXCEPT:1) Replace a camera. The built-in camera is only front-facing, which means it is designed for Skyping or taking photos of your own  face. It is prohibitively annoying to try to photograph anything else, especially if the object has text on it, which will photograph backwards, like a mirror. You will not be able to transfer photos directly from your camera to the Kindle with a PC in between or an expensive eye-fi sd card.2) Because the Kindle doesn't natively support Adobe Flash you'll do a lot of jumping through hoops to view a lot of web content without finding and using external apps. It's rather difficult sometime to upload things from the Kindle to the cloud without a PC in between.3) It has a lot of great apps, but not all Android apps work. There are some workarounds if you're at least a little computer savvy and good at searching the web4) No matter what the hype says, the battery in the 8.9 can't handle the load. It runs down much quicker than the 7" and takes FOREVER to charge, even with the much hyped special Kindle charger. Lots of crap is going on in the background that you don't realize. Always turn the wireless off if you are not using it. Don't rely on standby, shut the system down if you are not using it.If any of these things disturb you, please spend a few more hundred dollars and get an i-Pud, oops, i-Pad.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic!
Reviews.Author: The Butterfly
Reviews.Content: I absolutely love it because it meets my needs. It's a great product! I am satisfied with my upgraded Kindle.

Reviews.Title: TURN OFF ADVERTISING
Reviews.Author: Dennis Schwarm
Reviews.Content: I actually like how the kindle functions butREALLY DISLIKEthe advertisements that are all over including when i turn it on!!My ipad and surface doesn't!For this reason alone I would not recommend or buy another

Reviews.Title: refurbished is a no no
Reviews.Author: Kamela Gomez
Reviews.Content: I have had nothing but problems with this Kindle. My original Kindle never gave me a problem but then I bought this one and it has been frozen more than it has worked!  I am very disappointed!

Reviews.Title: Nightmare experience with Amazon
Reviews.Author: Mary McMahon
Reviews.Content: I did not chose a refurbished device, and wouldn't have done so.  I was under the impression that I ordered a new device and was surprised to discover that my "new" device was not new after all.  The term refurbished was never disclosed to me..  The device I received was inferior.  There were "dead spots" on the screen and I was unable to access my email for days at a time.  I subsequently returned this one for a brand new device.Would I recommend this to anyone?  I'm afraid I would not.I have also had problems with my new Kindle Fire.  I still am not able to access my email for days, and then all of a sudden, the emails will appear, but only from the date that the emails stopped.  I am so frustrated with this whole experience, and it has left me with  a bad feeling for Amazon.  All levels of technical support have been unable to fix this problem, or to explain what the problem actually is.  Any suggestions??

Reviews.Title: Paper weight
Reviews.Author: brian
Reviews.Content: I've had this Kindle for about 14 months and it suddenly became a paper weight.  Upon powering the device on, the "kindlefire" logo appears and that's it.  It won't do anything else.  Customer service has said that it can't be fixed and that my only option is to buy a new one.  I loved this device, but it is completely useless and infuriating now.  Not worth it, buy something more reliable.

Reviews.Title: I expected better
Reviews.Author: Clara McKennett
Reviews.Content: I am surprisingly disappointed with the Fire HD 8.9".  I want to love it, but it has some clunky features that make it not very loveable to me.  I am also an owner of a first generation Fire which I loved.  If it didn't have charging issues, I would not have sought a replacement.I will start with the good points.The screen is lovely, large and clear.Overall, it is not heavy for the size.There are more apps available on this version and some are ones that I had been wishing for.The browser is much more stable.The e-mail program is far superior.Now for the bad points.The charging port could not be in a worse location.  It is right at the bottom of the screen.  For someone holding the tablet while charging it is either pointing at you, potentially causing harm to the port or pointing straight up which means it is in your way constantly.  It was on the side on the first generation and is on the HDX so I guess lessson learned from this model.  If you like to watch video while using a standing cover like I do, you have to delicately balance it on the edge of a table or dresser so the charging cord can be plugged in.The mini HDMI port is in the same location with the same issues.The power button is inferior, it is hard to push, it is a small rectangular button flush with the edge of the screen.  It also does not have any indicator light.  The only way to know that your tablet is charging is to open the cover, turn it on and look at the corner of the screen.  That's also the only way to know the charge is complete.  The first gen had a nice round button on the side, it glowed orange while charging or starting up and green when the charge was complete.These issues seem minor until you realize how much time you are going to be charging this tablet.  It takes hours to charge, probably close to 4 or 5 for a full charge.  I use the tablet for about 30 minutes in the morning, surfing the web and checking e-mail and then in the evening for the same for another 45 minutes or so and then to stream 2 hours or so of video.  That fully depletes the battery daily.  If I forget to charge during the day, I have to have it plugged in while I stream the video which requires dealing with the charging cord hanging out of the bottom.In short, I should have ponied up the money for the HDX, but I didn't check these features before buying.  It honestly didn't occur to me.  I'd give it at A for software and a D for hardware.

Reviews.Title: Disappointed.
Reviews.Author: C. Hari "Look Ahead"
Reviews.Content: I had Kindle Fire first generation. I now bought this expecting it would be much superior. Though the screen is HD, the silk browser is at its worst. Often crashes. The device itself is so slow, I would rather go back to the old device.Not much difference as a book reader. I was expecting improvement from the 1st generation device. Not much, besides HD.This is a huge disappointment.

Reviews.Title: good but not great
Reviews.Author: meme
Reviews.Content: I had a earlier kindle and upgraded to this. But the battery stinks on this one. It always seems to need to be charged then it takes forever to charge. So I feel like I am always waiting on the kindle.

Reviews.Title: Not Bad but Not Great
Reviews.Author: Nathan T. Stitt
Reviews.Content: I got a great deal on this or I would not have purchased. It handles many things very well, and my favorite things are reading a news app and watching Prime videos. My kids like playing the games. However, there are two things that would prevent me from buying another one.First, the silk browser is not good. It struggles with many web sites and is very poorly implemented. Speed isn't an issue, usability is. I sometimes do not visit links because I don't want to fight the silk browser. This would be less of a problem if not for the second issue, which is huge. Kindle's are locked out of many apps for android devices. I knew this going in and almost did not buy one for this reason. You simply cannot download many android apps. It sucks. Can't replace the silk browser. Can't use many apps.I would recommend the Kindle for someone that is not very interested in app variety and if you can get them for a cheap price. Not worth the MSRP, but they frequently go on sale. If you are a heavy Prime video user and don't require much variety in apps, or want one to read from they are worth while I guess. I don't plan to buy another one at this time. I'll get a regular android tablet next time. The only exception would be if I got one for my kids to use.So high marks for value, build quality, and multimedia. Low marks for poor internet browser and extremely limited app options. Unless you want a dumbed down tablet or Kindle-specific features get a proper android tablet. Amazon needs to open up the store and change their tactics here...

Reviews.Title: This replaced my original Kindle Fire
Reviews.Author: curious cook
Reviews.Content: My Kindle fire simply froze after I'd owned it for two years, and I have to give Amazon five stars on how they handled my out-of-warranty device. They offered my a very reasonable deal on this replacement, along with several other options, and shipped it immediately before I had shipped back my malfunctioning device. I have never had a bad experience with Amazon customer service.That said, my new 8.9" HD device can be very touchy. Sometimes the touch screen will freeze up, and I will have to do a hard reset two or three times before it will unfreeze. At other times, the screen will vibrate like it has delirium tremons. Then it will lull me into complacency by working fine for several days. Then we're back to all the quirks. Quite annoying, and not at all like my experience with the original fire, which was amazingly dependable until it just melted down.I will say the HD picture is quite nice, and visibly sharper than the original fire. And the sound from the built-in speakers is impressive for their size.

Reviews.Title: Terrible with e-mails
Reviews.Author: Paul Petrilli "Paul in TN"
Reviews.Content: If I knew that this device was not e-mail user friendly, I would have never bought it.  I am tempted to sell or give it away and get an I-Pad

Reviews.Title: Replacment
Reviews.Author: E. Matsko
Reviews.Content: What great customer service.  My just 1 yr old Kindle WI-FI stopped and Amazon replaced it.  It works great once again.Thanks so muchEric

Reviews.Title: Amazon Service
Reviews.Author: Gregory J. Bartels "gb"
Reviews.Content: I was a huge fan of Amazon until this week. The 32 GB Kindle Fire HD showed up with only .98 GB and many other problems with apps such as Facebook and Skype. Their customer service is terrible, the representatives and the systems are not capable of solving or properly escalating many of the problems with the hardware and software.
